abstract.p: National Venture Capital Association reports that $24.billion in venture capital was invested in second quarter of 2000, compared with $24.8 billion in first quarter; says that during quarter electronic-commerce companies fell out of favor with venture capitalists, whose Internet-related investments focused increasingly on communications and infrastructure startups; graph (M)

block.p: Even as the public stock markets cooled, the level of venture capital investment nationwide was little changed in the second quarter, the National Venture Capital Association reported yesterday.

In fact, more companies received investments in the April-June period than in either of the previous two quarters, though the amount invested declined slightly for the second consecutive quarter after growing at a blistering pace last year.
Even as the public stock markets cooled, the level of venture capital investment nationwide was little changed in the second quarter, the National Venture Capital Association reported yesterday.

In fact, more companies received investments in the April-June period than in either of the previous two quarters, though the amount invested declined slightly for the second consecutive quarter after growing at a blistering pace last year.
And the survey found that electronic-commerce companies had fallen out of favor, with Internet-related investments focused increasingly on communications and infrastructure start-ups.

The survey found the nation's 640 venture capital firms, and the venture investment arms of corporations, poured $24.5 billion into 1,695 companies, compared with investments of $24.8 billion in 1,627 companies in the first quarter.
Still, the increase from a year earlier was striking. In the second quarter of 1999, $12.5 billion was invested in 1,168 start-ups.

But since April, when technology stock prices dropped precipitously, some venture capitalists have said that they are investing in start-ups less aggressively than they did last year, wary that they will not be able to take the companies public so readily.

Jeanne Metzger, director of marketing for the National Venture Capital Association, an industry trade group, said the present rate of investment showed that venture firms were still financing entrepreneurs at a healthy rate.

''The V.C. industry continues to grow at a strong pace,'' she said, particularly ''when you take into account that this was a period of substantial market volatility.'' She added that the fact that the investment rate leveled off should not be cause for concern because the growth in investing last year -- an increase of 150 percent over the total in 1998 -- was unsustainable.

The survey, conducted in conjunction with Venture Economics, a division of Thomson Financial Securities Data, found that Internet-related investments grew to $19.9 billion in the second quarter, from $19 billion in the previous period. Of such investments, communications and infrastructure companies -- like those focused on wireless technology, telephony, or voice and data transmission -- attracted 26.9 percent, compared with 20.1 percent in the first quarter.
E-commerce companies, in contrast, attracted 14.5 percent of Internet-related investments, compared with 27.2 percent in the first quarter.
